 How Luminol Works  Luminol
is an incredible compound that crime scene investigators use to reveal traces
of blood at crime scenes. Learn how luminol works, how investigators use it and
about the process known as chemiluminescence. 
Also at HowStuffWorks
 
How
Plasma Cutters Work - It may
sound like something out of a sci-fi novel, but the plasma cutter is actually a
common tool that has been around since World War II. Using the power of plasma,
these machines cut through extremely hard metals. Find out how plasma cutters
work.
 

How
Facial Recognition Systems Work - You've
probably seen it in a dozen movies and television shows: sophisticated computer
programs identifying criminals by analyzing their facial structures. These
depictions aren't always accurate, but it's still remarkable technology. Find
out how facial recognition systems work and learn what a faceprint is.
 

How
Sunburns and Sun Tans Work - Treading
the fine line between a sunburn and a sun tan is a challenge for many
beachgoers. In this article, learn how the sun affects your skin and how much
sun exposure is too much.
   
This Week's Video
 How
Silly String Works - Silly String is a fun and, yes, silly toy that has some interesting science behind it.
It's even been adapted by soldiers in Iraq to check for trip wires. In
this video from HowStuffWorks, watch and learn how Silly String works.
